Magnatone | website = }} '''Billy Montana''' (born '''William Schlappi''' on September 28, 1959, in [[Voorheesville, New York]]) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Between 1987 and 1995, Montana released one studio album and charted six singles on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart. As a songwriter, Montana's songs have been recorded by [[Lee Brice]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[Sara Evans]], [[Jo Dee Messina]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Martina McBride]], [[Jon Pardi]], [[Sister Hazel]] and [[Kenny Rogers]], among others.{{Cite web |url=http://www.morainemusic.com/writerpages/billymontana.html |title=Moraine Music Group |access-date=July 25, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719040312/http://www.morainemusic.com/writerpages/billymontana.html |archive-date=July 19, 2008 |url-status=dead }} ==Career== ===Singer=== In the late 1980s, Montana and his brother, Kyle, formed a country music group with Bobby Kendall, Dave Flint and Doug Bernhard.[http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/233039 Curb Music at BMI] '''Billy Montana & the Long Shots''' signed with [[Warner Bros. Records]] and charted three singles on ''Billboard'''s Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart before disbanding without releasing an album. Their highest charting single, "Baby I Was Leaving Anyhow," peaked at No. 40 in 1987. After the group disbanded, Montana moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 1989 to pursue his dream of songwriting. In 1994, Magnatone Records signed Montana to a solo record deal.[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p169659/biography|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( Billy Montana > Biography )))] His debut album, ''No Yesterday'', was released in April 1995.[{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r229264|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( No Yesterday > Biography )))] Three singles were released from the project and charted on ''Billboard'''s Hot Country Singles & Tracks, the highest of which peaked at No. 55. One of the album's tracks, "A Clean Mind and Dirty Hands," was named Song of the Year by [[Farm Journal]] in 1996 as the song best depicting genuine farm life. ===Songwriter=== Montana was signed to a songwriting deal with Moraine Music in 1994. He was picked up by Curb Publishing in a joint venture in 2000. The following year, Jo Dee Messina released Montana's "[[Bring On the Rain]]" as a single. The song topped ''Billboard'''s Hot Country Singles & Tracks in March 2002 and was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]]. Montana has since written No. 1 songs for Sara Evans ("[[Suds in the Bucket]]"), Lee Brice ("[[Hard to Love (Lee Brice song)|Hard to Love]]"), and Garth Brooks ("[[More Than a Memory]]"). "More Than a Memory" debuted at No. 1 on ''Billboard'''s [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in September 2007, becoming the first song in the chart's entire history to accomplish that feat.[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1049494/soulja-boy-cranks-hot-100-no-1-with-debut-single Soulja Boy 'Cranks' Hot 100 No. 1 With Debut Single] ===Family=== Billy Montana's son, [[Randy Montana]], signed to [[Mercury Nashville]] in 2010.
